working_definition: Deaf-Blindness is a combination of hearing and visual impairments that causes severe communication, developmental, and educational needs. These impairments are so significant that they cannot be accommodated in special education programs solely for children with deafness or blindness.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Congenital Deaf-Blindness
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: A condition present at birth or before language is acquired, often due to genetic disorders or prenatal complications.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Acquired Deaf-Blindness
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: A condition acquired later in life, such as through illness, injury, or aging-related causes like Usher Syndrome.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Usher Syndrome
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: A genetic condition that causes both hearing loss and progressive vision loss.

common_presentations: Difficulty accessing spoken or visual information in the classroom
Limited or unconventional communication methods (e.g., tactile signing, object symbols)
Needs one-on-one support to navigate environments
Delayed social interaction or isolation from peers
Requires specialized instruction for concept development
Difficulty with orientation and mobility in unfamiliar settings
Inconsistent response to visual or auditory cues
Sensory overload in busy or noisy environments
Strong reliance on touch or physical prompts
Delayed expressive and receptive language development

accommodations_modifications.name: Use of tactile symbols or object cues
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Supports communication for students with limited vision and hearing
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Limited or unconventional communication methods (e.g., tactile signing, object symbols)
accommodations_modifications.example: Student uses a spoon to indicate mealtime and a book to indicate reading

accommodations_modifications.name: One-on-one intervener support
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Facilitates communication, mobility, and learning in all environments
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Needs one-on-one support to navigate environments
accommodations_modifications.example: An intervener assists the student during transitions between classes

accommodations_modifications.name: Provide instruction in tactile sign language or adapted communication system
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Enables expressive and receptive communication for students with combined sensory loss
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Delayed expressive and receptive language development
accommodations_modifications.example: Teacher uses tactile ASL to deliver lesson instructions

accommodations_modifications.name: Hands-on, real-life learning experiences
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Enhances concept development through direct experience
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Requires specialized instruction for concept development
accommodations_modifications.example: Student participates in cooking to understand measurement and sequence

accommodations_modifications.name: Consistent physical cues for transitions and routines
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Reduces confusion and prepares students for changes in activity
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Inconsistent response to visual or auditory cues
accommodations_modifications.example: Student receives a tap on the shoulder before transitioning to the next subject

accommodations_modifications.name: Use of vibrating alerts or tactile timers
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Supports independence and time awareness without needing visual or auditory input
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Difficulty accessing spoken or visual information in the classroom
accommodations_modifications.example: Student uses a vibrating watch for scheduled tasks

accommodations_modifications.name: Teach orientation and mobility with specialized tools
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Supports safe navigation in and around school
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Difficulty with orientation and mobility in unfamiliar settings
accommodations_modifications.example: Student learns to navigate hallways with a mobility cane and guide

accommodations_modifications.name: Use of consistent peer partners
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Supports social connection and builds interaction opportunities
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Delayed social interaction or isolation from peers
accommodations_modifications.example: Student is paired with a peer for lunch and recess activities

accommodations_modifications.name: Environmental modifications for reduced sensory overload
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Helps the student focus by limiting sensory distractions
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Sensory overload in busy or noisy environments
accommodations_modifications.example: Student works in a quiet corner with soft lighting and minimal clutter

accommodations_modifications.name: Provide instruction with physical demonstrations
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Makes abstract content accessible through tactile experiences
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Difficulty accessing spoken or visual information in the classroom
accommodations_modifications.example: Student explores 3D shapes with their hands while learning geometry
